isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - DIAGNOSTIC TOOLS AND ACCESSORIES - Tools and Accessories - Slack Tube Manometer

svcproc.title: Slack Tube Manometer
svcproc.para: The manometer is a U-shaped tube with a scale mounted between the legs of the U. When the portability of the gauge bar tool is not required, this manometer is used to measure either low pressure or vacuum (intake restriction, crankcase pressure or exhaust back pressure).

The manometer must be filled with water before checking any pressure. Use only drinking water without additives. Add some colored water vegetable dye so the scale can be read more easily. With both legs of the manometer open to the atmosphere, fill the tube until the top of the fluid column is near the zero mark on the scale. Shake the tube to eliminate any air bubbles.

note.para: Never fill the manometer with an antifreeze solution, soda pop, tonic, etc. The increase in density causes false readings.

step1.para: Support the manometer in a vertical position. Make sure the fluid level is in line with the zero indicator on the graduated scale.
Connect one leg of the manometer to the source of the pressure or vacuum. The other leg is left open to atmospheric pressure.
Start the engine and allow it to reach normal operating temperature. Then run the engine to high idle. The manometer can be observed after approximately 10 seconds.

Record the average position of the fluid level when it is above and below the zero indicator. Add the two figures together. The sum of the two is the total column of fluid (distance A). This represents the crankcase pressure in inches of water (in H 2O).
At times, both columns of the manometer will not travel the same distance. This is of no concern as long as the leg that is not connected to the pressure or vacuum source is open to the atmosphere.
Compare the manometer reading with engine specifications.
When test is finished, clean the tube thoroughly using a little pure soap and water. Avoid liquid soaps and solvents.
